details:
A critical remote code execution vulnerability was discovered in the Python interpreter's handling of specially crafted pickle data. An attacker could exploit this to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the Python process.

This vulnerability affects all Python applications that deserialize untrusted pickle data. For more information, see https://docs.python.org/3/library/pickle.html#restricting-globals
A high-severity buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the ssl module when processing malformed certificates. This could lead to denial of service or information disclosure.
An improper input validation vulnerability in the urllib.parse module allows attackers to bypass URL validation checks. This could be exploited in SSRF attacks.

A medium-severity vulnerability in the zipfile module allows directory traversal when extracting files from a malicious archive. Applications that extract zip files from untrusted sources may be affected.

The http.server module exposes sensitive directory listing information that could aid attackers in reconnaissance. While not directly exploitable, this information disclosure can be used as part of a larger attack chain.

A low-severity timing side-channel vulnerability in the hmac module could theoretically allow an attacker to recover secret key material under very specific conditions. Practical exploitation is considered extremely difficult.
Minor information disclosure in error messages that could reveal internal path information. Impact is limited as this requires local access to trigger the error condition.

CRITICAL: A maximum severity vulnerability allows unauthenticated remote code execution via the eval() function when used with user-controlled input. All applications using eval() with untrusted data are affected.

IMPORTANT: This is an extremely dangerous vulnerability. Apply patches immediately or implement the recommended mitigations.

See https://python.org/security/critical-2025-0008 for emergency patching instructions.
